tier_0_classification.classification_reasoning: This is a numerical calculation problem that requires interpreting data from a pie chart (image) and a table, then performing multiple calculations to find the total fat consumption. It integrates concepts of diet, energy density, and percentages, making it a medium difficulty problem.

answer_validation.reasoning: From the pie chart: Carbohydrates 35%, Proteins 20%, Unsaturated fat 20%, Saturated fat 20%, Trans fat 5%. Total fat percentage = 20 + 20 + 5 = 45% of the 2,000 kcal diet. Thus energy from fat = 0.45 \times 2000 = 900 kcal. All fats have energy density 9 kcal/g, so total fat mass = 900 / 9 = 100 g. This matches option C.

step_by_step: Step 1: Read the macronutrient percentages from the pie chart: Carbohydrates 35%, Proteins 20%, Unsaturated fat 20%, Saturated fat 20%, Trans fat 5%.
Step 2: Identify all types of fat: Unsaturated, Saturated, and Trans. Add their percentages to get total fat percentage: 20% + 20% + 5% = 45%.
Step 3: Compute total energy from fat in a 2,000 kcal diet: $E_{fat} = 0.45 \times 2000 = 900$ kcal.
Step 4: Use the given energy density of fat (9 kcal/g for all three types) to convert energy to mass: $m_{fat} = \dfrac{E_{fat}}{9} = \dfrac{900}{9} = 100$ g.
Step 5: Match this result with the options; 100 g corresponds to option C.

topic.name: General aptitude / numerical reasoning with percentages
topic.syllabus_ref: GATE General Aptitude: Data interpretation and numerical calculations

concepts.name: Unit conversion between energy and mass using density

essential: Understanding of percentages and how to convert them to fractions
Ability to read and interpret pie charts
Concept of energy density (kcal per gram)
helpful: Familiarity with nutritional labeling (kcal, grams of macronutrients)
Comfort with dimensional analysis for unit conversion

Main Concept: requires: Understanding of percentages and fractions
requires: Concept of energy density (kcal per gram)
enables: Interpreting nutritional information from food labels
enables: Solving more complex data-interpretation problems involving units and conversions

difficulty_factors: Requires correctly summing only the fat percentages from the pie chart
Needs recognition that all three fat types share the same energy density, simplifying the calculation

textbook_references.author: NCERT or equivalent
textbook_references.text_snippet: Examples of interpreting pie charts and converting sector percentages into actual quantities.

video_references.topic_covered: Pie chart data interpretation and percentage calculations

step_by_step_solution.solution_path: Read percentages from pie chart \u2192 Sum fat percentages \u2192 Compute energy from fat \u2192 Convert energy to grams using density \u2192 Choose closest option
key_insights: Only the three fat sectors contribute to \"total fat\"; carbohydrates and proteins are irrelevant for this specific question.
Because all fats have the same energy density, you can sum their energy percentages before converting to grams.

formulas_principles.name: Energy from fat based on percentage contribution
formulas_principles.conditions: Here $p_{fat}$ is the total percentage of energy from all fat types and $E_{total}$ is total dietary energy.
formulas_principles.relevance: Used to compute how many kcal come from fat in the 2,000 kcal diet.

formulas_principles.name: Mass from energy using energy density
formulas_principles.conditions: Applies when energy density $e_{fat}$ is given in kcal/g and $E_{fat}$ in kcal.
formulas_principles.relevance: Converts energy from fat into grams consumed.

industry_examples: Designing balanced meal plans where dietitians calculate grams of fat, protein, and carbohydrates from total caloric needs.
Food labeling regulations where manufacturers convert macronutrient grams into kcal to report total energy.
specific_systems: Nutritional planning for astronauts where precise macronutrient mass and energy are critical for mission logistics.
real_world_applications.practical_relevance: Understanding how energy density relates mass of nutrients to caloric intake is important for health, mission planning, and even aircraft weight calculations when provisioning food for long flights.

common_mistakes.mistake: Including carbohydrates and proteins when summing percentages for total fat, leading to 100% and then dividing 2000 kcal by 9 kcal/g.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: They rush and do not read \"total fat (all three types)\" carefully, assuming all macronutrients are to be included.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Underline what is being asked (here, only fat). Before calculating, list explicitly which sectors of the pie chart are relevant.
common_mistakes.consequence: Gives 222.2 g instead of any option, causing confusion and likely a wrong guess.

common_mistakes.mistake: Using 4 kcal/g (value for carbohydrates/proteins) instead of 9 kcal/g for fats.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: They memorize one common value (4 kcal/g) and apply it blindly.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Remember the pattern: fats are more energy dense (9 kcal/g) than carbs/proteins (4 kcal/g). Always check the table before substituting.
common_mistakes.consequence: Leads to 900/4 = 225 g, which does not match any option.

common_mistakes.mistake: Forgetting to convert percentage to fraction (using 45 instead of 0.45).
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: They directly multiply 45 by 2000 without dividing by 100.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Always write the conversion explicitly: $p\% = p/100$ before multiplying.
common_mistakes.consequence: Results in 90,000 kcal from fat, then 10,000 g of fat, clearly unrealistic.

mnemonics_memory_aids.mnemonic: Fats are Fine at Nine; Carbs & Proteins score Four.
mnemonics_memory_aids.concept: Remembering energy densities: 9 kcal/g for fats, 4 kcal/g for carbohydrates and proteins.
mnemonics_memory_aids.context: Use whenever converting between kcal and grams for macronutrients.

flashcards.front: How do you compute energy from a nutrient that contributes p% of a total E kcal diet?
flashcards.back: Use $E_{nutrient} = (p/100) \times E$. Example: 45% of 2000 kcal = 0.45 \times 2000 = 900 kcal.

flashcards.front: What are the typical energy densities (kcal/g) of fats vs carbohydrates/proteins?
flashcards.back: Fats (unsaturated, saturated, trans): 9 kcal/g. Carbohydrates and proteins: 4 kcal/g.

flashcards.front: In a 2,500 kcal diet, 30% of energy is from fat (9 kcal/g). How many grams of fat is that?
flashcards.back: Energy from fat = 0.30 \times 2500 = 750 kcal. Mass = 750 / 9 \approx 83.3 g.

flashcards.front: What is the first check before using a kcal/g value from a table?
flashcards.back: Confirm you are using the correct energy density for that macronutrient (4 for carbs/proteins, 9 for fats).

real_world_context.application: Designing in-flight meals for passengers and crew on long-haul flights.
real_world_context.industry_example: Airlines compute total calories and grams of fat per meal to meet nutritional guidelines while controlling total mass loaded on the aircraft.
real_world_context.why_it_matters: Over- or under-estimating macronutrient mass affects both passenger health and payload/weight calculations.

exam_strategy.triage_tip: Scan the pie chart, quickly jot down the relevant percentages, and perform one multiplication and one division. If numbers are clean (like 2000 kcal, 45%), it is a quick scoring question.
exam_strategy.guessing_heuristic: If stuck, remember that fats are more energy dense; so grams of fat must be less than total kcal. Eliminate any option larger than 2000 g or clearly unrealistic.
exam_strategy.time_management: Aim to finish within 1â€“2 minutes; do not overthink since it is a direct percentage and unit-conversion problem.

search_keywords: energy density kcal per gram fats carbohydrates proteins
GATE general aptitude nutrition pie chart problem
convert calories to grams of fat

alternative_methods.name: Per-gram calorie balance check
alternative_methods.description: Assume x grams of total fat. Then energy from fat is 9x kcal. Set 9x equal to 45% of 2000 kcal and solve: 9x = 0.45 \times 2000, giving x = 100 g.
alternative_methods.pros_cons: Pros: Reinforces algebraic thinking and can generalize to unknown total calories. Cons: Slightly longer than direct percentage then division.
alternative_methods.when_to_use: Useful when the total energy is not given directly but expressed in terms of another variable.

connections_to_other_subjects.Thermodynamics: Concept of specific energy (kcal/g) parallels specific internal energy (kJ/kg) or specific enthalpy used in energy balance problems.
connections_to_other_subjects.Flight Mechanics: Mass of consumables like food contributes to aircraft weight and range calculations, similar to fuel mass.
connections_to_other_subjects.Propulsion: Energy per unit mass is analogous to calorific value of fuels used in engines and rockets.

deeper_dive_topics: Specific energy and energy density concepts in fuels and propellants
Optimization of payload mass including consumables in aircraft and spacecraft missions

syllabus_mapping.feedback_for_syllabus_design: Excellent example of integrating real-life nutritional context with percentage and unit-conversion skills.

rag_quality.notes: RAG context focused on aerospace topics like standard atmosphere, fatigue, and shocks, which were not needed for this general aptitude nutrition/percentage problem. Solution relied entirely on basic arithmetic and internal knowledge.

future_questions_potential: Given grams of each macronutrient, ask for total caloric intake and percentage from fats.
Modify energy densities slightly and ask students to recompute total grams of each macronutrient.
Introduce constraints such as maximum allowed fat grams and ask if a given diet plan satisfies them.

response_json.subject: General Aptitude
response_json.question_text:
The pie chart presents the percentage contribution of different macronutrients to a typical 2,000 kcal diet of a person.
The typical energy density (kcal/g) of these macronutrients is given in the table.

[Table data]
Macronutrient | Energy density (kcal/g)
Carbohydrates | 4
Proteins | 4
Unsaturated fat | 9
Saturated fat | 9
Trans fat | 9

The total fat (all three types), in grams, this person consumes is
